The treatment plan includes confirmed tissue diagnosis via biopsy, staging with imaging (such as MRI, CT, or PET scan), and prompt oncological staging to assess disease extent. Initial management should prioritize stabilization of heavy bleeding—potentially using vaginal packing, tranexamic acid, or hormonal therapy temporarily—while preparing for definitive treatment.  Key interventions involve referral to gynecologic oncology for consideration of radical hysterectomy (if early-stage and feasible), or concurrent chemoradiation as the standard of care for advanced or high-risk disease. Chemotherapy agents such as cisplatin with radiation are first-line, supported by evidence demonstrating improved survival. Supportive measures include blood transfusions as needed, pain management, infection control, and psycho-social support.  In addition to medical treatments, patient education will focus on understanding the disease process, treatment options, potential side effects, and signs of complication requiring urgent care—such as severe bleeding, signs of infection, or systemic deterioration.  Follow-up care involves close monitoring of treatment response with periodic imaging and clinical assessment every 4-6 weeks during active therapy, with ongoing symptom management. The patient should be instructed to report immediately if she experiences worsening bleeding, severe pain, fever, or systemic symptoms.  Given her baseline communication and health status, I will approach this with clear, empathetic explanations, emphasizing collaboration and supporting adherence to complex treatment regimens. Coordination with multidisciplinary teams—including gynecologic oncology, radiation oncology, palliative care, and social services—is essential.
